## **20 Fresh Employee Engagement Ideas for 2020**

The trends mentioned above, along with the growing emphasis on **[candidate
experience](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/recruitment-
onboarding/what-is-candidate-experience-definition-components-technology/)**
and employee experience, demand not only attention but action as well. So,
let's look at 20 fresh employee engagement ideas for 2020.

### **1\. Celebrate what employees achieve in their downtime**

  
HR should be mindful of an employee's 360-degree goals and targets, even
outside the workplace. Someone may be an accomplished artist, chef, or
marathon runner – and recognition in these areas is as important as typical
workplace recognition.

An excellent employee engagement activity for 2020 would be hosting weekly
meetups where every employee/team shares stories of their downtime pursuits,
what they have achieved and future hopes/goals.

**Learn More:**[ **How to Engage Employees in 2020: 10 Impactful
Solutions**](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/employee-engagement/how-
to-engage-employees-impactful-
solutions/?zd_source=hrt&zd_campaign=4962&zd_term=prarthanaghosh)

### **2\. Upgrade communications to include video**

  
Your upgraded intranets, frequent mailers, and a cake-for-every-occasion can
only take you so far. They will not crack the code to the ultimate employee
experience. To truly provide the fabled "holistic experience for a
multigenerational workforce," you must crack the video code.

Every employee is a consumer, and if video content works better for your
external customers, it would work for your internal customers too.

A video is also an excellent tool for pan-company announcements and to engage
with your deskless workforce, your gig workers, and your remote workers.

Everyone loves a bit of the limelight, and broadcasting short culture-centric
videos of real employees speaking about their achievements and aspirations
helps to build a strong connection with the rest of your workforce. For people
who don't come to headquarters every day, videos can help them feel connected
with their teams and give them a sense of belonging and engagement.

### **3\. Give your pulse surveys a makeover**

  
With Google Forms and SurveyMonkey, you can create pulse surveys with ease and
customize them to suit your needs. But who says that a survey needs to look
and feel like a survey? Ticking through boxes of endless options and choosing
numbers on a Likert scale are not the only way that your employees can tell
you how engaged they are.

You could ask for short WhatsApp voice notes not more than 20 seconds long –
an easy investment for your employees and for you – that encapsulates how the
week went. You could even do the same by asking them to upload a picture a
week.

Employees could also take a quick mood test, or engagement analytics tools
that study search trends within work systems that could give you a glimpse of
the general mood throughout the organization.

### **4\. Implement a non-anonymized survey to measure the engagement**

  
Anonymizing the results of an **[employee engagement
survey](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/employee-engagement/what-is-
an-employee-engagement-survey-definition-process-vendors-examples/)** has
always been a best practice. And this continues to hold for more formal
surveys, where you measure company-wide engagement/satisfaction levels. But
you could also implement a non-anonymized survey for small teams and employee
groups.

Make this a fun employee engagement activity – hand out post-its after a
meeting where employees can jot down their feedback with a clear signature.
This will help them take ownership of feedback and feel like they are being
heard as individuals, and not as an anonymized voice in a dataset.

### **5\. Enable remote working**

  
The modern office is not a place but a function, and in our age of instant
(and constant!) connectivity, this function could be carried out from
anywhere. If your company policy does not allow a work-from-home option, it
costs you the chance to hire and engage a massive variety of diverse talent.

It is not just millennials who demand remote working tools and flexible
culture. While they would make up 75% of the workforce by 2020, the minority
generations at work would benefit as well.

Creating a culture that is anytime-anywhere (by using collaborative systems
like Slack, easy video-calling solutions, and ensuring regular check-ins)
makes your mobile workforce feel valued and trusted.

That is a sure boost to engagement because then work becomes a more enjoyable
exercise where employees' values, goals, and vision can coexist with those of
the organization.

### **6\. But say goodbye to the always-on culture for a week every quarter**

  
It isn't always possible to switch off every time we step out of the office –
but you could make it a mandate for at least one week a quarter, where
employees must remain unavailable outside of work hours. Convey clearly that
no one should expect a response to an email or an instant message during this
week once the employee has left for the day.

Activities like these are critical to reduce burnout and ensure that employees
are adequately refreshed to maintain optimal productivity levels. They also
help employees feel cared for, just like the company's customers.

### **7\. Encourage employees to become company brand ambassadors**

  
Your employer brand needs storytellers. Cultivating a band of employee brand
ambassadors serves a two-fold purpose – fostering a strong sense of pride and
belongingness within employees and building a credible employer brand that
candidates, clients, and external points of contact can believe in.

With employees being active contributors on platforms like Snapchat,
Instagram, LinkedIn, and Glassdoor, the art of branded storytelling can be
more effective and is more critical than ever before. A lot of millennials
especially engage while engaging others and thrive in an environment that
allows them to express their views and opinions on social platforms.

### **8\. Invest in gamification at different levels of the employee
lifecycle**

  
We've all heard of how gamified candidate selection or gamified corporate
learning has been creating ripples. But often, considerable shifts in
technology and strategy are usually a "them" change before they become an "us"
change.

While new-age technology can help you elevate gamification, you could put
gamified processes to use even without futuristic tech. Game-based learning
not only boosts productivity levels, but also brings in a note of fun that
encourages a bit of friendly competition, enhances collaboration, and elevates
the drive to succeed.

You could assign a day for some trivia quizzed on general knowledge and the
company's brand or have a monthly tournament of Chess or Settlers of Catan,
where teams have to collaborate strategically. Introducing relevant games such
as these into the company culture would only enhance the overall employee
experience.

**Learn More:**[ **Employee Engagement vs. Employee Experience: Are They
Really That Different?**](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/employee-
engagement/employee-engagement-vs-employee-experience-are-they-different/)

### **9\. Offer a two-way mentorship program across departments**

  
Two-way mentorship programs are an excellent strategy for upskilling and
employee engagement. They open up employees to new areas of learning and can
serve as the key to unlocking hidden talent. It also helps employees
understand their role in the larger organization.

For example, consider a two-way mentorship between a software developer and a
marketer. The former gets to know how their product is positioned in the
market, while the latter receives a hands-on idea of the product they are
marketing. In the long-term, this strategy also has the potential to bolster
your productivity levels.

**Learn More:** **[5 Key Learning Management System (LMS) Trends in
2019](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-development/top-lms-
trends/)**

### **10\. Host frequent workshops**

  
As adults, we tend to be averse to stepping outside our comfort zones and
learning new things. That is where fun workshops can shake things up.
Moreover, this does not necessarily entail having to scour the market for
expensive coaches. You could source expertise internally as well.

For example, similar to the mentorship program, one of the coders could take a
two-day workshop on basic HTML so that everyone in the product development
team knows what goes on in the backend. Workshops could also be engaging
brainstorming sessions or fun ideas like cocktail-making or baking that help
people get out of their routine while making them connect the balance of
different ingredients in a cocktail or a cake to the need for diversity at
work, for example.

### **11\. Check your team's alignment to the organization's vision**

  
The why of the organization – why it exists, why we do things the way we do
them, or why we wish to achieve one goal before another – is something that
every employee needs to understand and be on board with before they can truly
be engaged at work.

Vision alignment or being in sync with the vision of the organization is an
essential pillar of engagement, and employees need to feel that the work that
they do matters and adds fuels the mission of the company.

The values and vision of the organization cannot exist merely on paper and
wall-decals – they need to be lived every day. To do this, there should be
enough scope for every employee to internalize what the organization stands
for and to align their own goals with organizational goals.

### **12\. Create an annual report of employee achievements**

  
At the end of every year, companies publish a formalized annual report that
shares its progress, achievements, and issues with the public. You can also
try a similar activity to increase employee engagement in 2020.

Review performance data to find areas of outstanding performance – this could
be hard skills leading to business results, or soft skills that positively
impacted the work environment. Represent this data in a visual format, using
charts, infographics, badges, etc. This will encourage similar results and
higher productivity in the new year.

### 13\. Involve the entire company when onboarding new hires

This is particularly relevant for small-to-mid-sized businesses. Even large
enterprises and 100% remote companies can leverage digital technology to
garner participation from every employee when someone new joins the company.

Hold a monthly onboarding day where the entire workforce gathers to welcome
new hires. You could also initiate a Slack thread called "Hello! Let me tell
you about myself," where current employees (from interns to C-leaders) can
tell the new hire something interesting about themselves. This will ensure
that employees are primed for engagement right from day one.

Besides, for remote workers, instead of sending across the link to a recorded
onboarding session, send them shorter video messages from team leaders and
their teammates to inspire them.

### **14\. Invest in wellness at work**

  
A [report by Humana](https://www.humana.com/employer/group-benefits-101/after-
enrollment/manage-employee-benefits/the-wellness-effect-the-impact-of-
workplace-programs/') called "The Wellness Effect: The Impact of Workplace
Programs" found that employee engagement and wellness are closely related. 67%
of employees in organizations that prioritize wellness said that they felt
more engaged with the values and vision of the organization.

Wellness at work does not have to be a compulsory yoga class. Wellness
incorporates within its umbrella physical, social, emotional, and financial
wellness. Your wellness plan needs to be able to cater to all these aspects
that cumulatively ensure the holistic health of an employee.

There is also a need to destigmatize mental health challenges that many
employees could be facing but feel uncomfortable to ask about. Building
systems in place for decreasing workplace stress is more than an absolute
necessity.

This is an opportunity to help your employees understand that you care for
their well-being, not merely to gain more productivity, but because that is
what the organization believes in. Better performance is often just the
byproduct of a healthy workplace.

### **15\. Revamp rewards and recognition**

  
Using AI to revamp rewards and recognition (R&R;) programs based on employee
feedback is a good way to get them more engaged. Employee engagement award
ideas that focus on rewarding behaviors that the organization values create a
sense of achievement for being in tune with the culture at work. The process
for nomination or voting for this should be fair and objective. This helps
further the cause of engagement.

Giving out fun awards like the messiest-desk-but-gets-the-job-done, marbles
under their feet award, or an award for always thinking outside the box are a
great way to get people to enjoy the process while also feeling valued and
appreciated for what they do.

### **16\. Make diversity and inclusion the norm**

  
Diversity and inclusion is yet another facet of work that needs to become more
than just a mandate. It would be a fresh change for your employees to see the
organization becoming more diverse. An environment that is an amalgamation of
cultural, gender, and [generational
diversity](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/culture/the-need-for-
generational-diversity-in-workplace/) is perceived to be alive and
interesting, and employees of all stripes thrive there.

Moreover, a culture that is sensitive to the needs thought patterns, and
ideologies of individuals from different cultures, backgrounds, and
generations are automatically more engaging.

To truly promote inclusivity, your organizational culture needs to allow every
voice to be heard. This involves allowing expression to individuals from
minority groups and those more prone to being discriminated against.

While taking the human out of certain screening processes could do away with
bias, installing feedback loop portals at work that address diversity issues
like 15Five, OfficeVibe and CultureAmp help in setting a mechanism in place
for employees to express their voice at work. Besides ensuring a better mix of
ideas and perspectives, inclusivity at work also makes employees feel valued
as individuals and not just a member of a specific group.

### **17\. Encourage work-life balance**

  
We live in a world where attaining a [work-life
balance](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/digital-transformation/four-
ways-ai-is-improving-worklife-balance/) is still considered a victory, whereas
it should be the norm. A regular working day should be one in which you get as
much time for yourself and your family as you do for work. The idea is to
create a schedule in which you do not feel like you are at a constant tug of
war between your duties at work and all that you want to accomplish outside of
work

Making employees always put in extra time and effort at work will lead to not
only burnout but also a noticeable dip in engagement. This is truer now when
we can always be connected to work, and where it could often be a challenge to
switch off our internal work mode.

A transparent, open, and enabling culture would allow employees to share their
voice out in case they do feel that managing work and life is becoming
difficult. Interventions should then be arranged to find out where the problem
lies and to make employees feel that they are not alone in their struggle.

[Voice-of-the-employee
technology](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/employee-engagement/what-
is-voice-of-the-employee-technology/), individualized [employee assistance
programs](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/benefits-administration/how-
employee-assistance-programs-improve-workplace-mental-health/) (EAPs), and
guided group counseling sessions are some resources that could be put in place
to create a culture that is inherently enabling and supportive.

### **18\. Plan creative CSR programs**

  
A [2019
study](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/283129700_Impact_of_corporate_social_responsibility_on_employee_engagement_A_case_of_Eskom_in_South_Africa/link/5a1f68e5aca272cbfbc2f166/download)
finds that employee engagement and corporate social responsibility (CSR) work
together to achieve organizational goals. It also found that business success
was partly driven by employee engagement arising from CSR.

A [study by Kenexa Research Institute](https://www.globenewswire.com/news-
release/2008/09/11/1225374/0/en/The-Kenexa-Research-Institute-Reveals-Exactly-
How-Engaged-Employees-Are-and-What-Exactly-Employee-Engagement-Means.html)
further asserts that how employees rate their pride in the organization, their
level of satisfaction at work, and their willingness to recommend their
organization to others is impacted by how they feel about the kind of work
that the organization does to give back to society.

A genuine focus on CSR and [sustainability at
work](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/culture/4-tips-to-create-a-
culture-of-sustainability-in-the-workplace/) and can help build a personal
connection between the organization, the employee and the society while also
harboring a sense of gratification in being able to add value to society at
large.

### **19\. Upgrade your EVP**

  
Employee value proposition (EVP) and **[employee
engagement](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/employee-engagement/what-
is-employee-engagement/)** are closely related and both fall on the employee
satisfaction/happiness spectrum. EVP plays a part in how the employee
perceives the employer brand right from the first telephonic interview until
their last day and their direct impact on the employees' level of engagement
and involvement at work.

Now is the time to upgrade your EVP – the promise that you make to your
employees. In a market as riddled with dynamism and as wrecked with the
competition, it is always helpful to take a step back and analyze what sets
you apart.

What is the USP of the employee experience that you are promising? How can you
deliver better on this promise and make your employees want to be engaged?

Answering these questions will help you move towards engagement practices that
are more organic and less transactional.

### **20\. Empower line managers to own employee engagement**

  
It is time to delegate the onus of employee engagement to individuals beyond
HR. [A white paper by Bain & Company](https://www.bain.com/insights/whos-
responsible-for-employee-engagement/') shows that companies like Rackspace,
AT&T;, Progressive Insurance, Intuit, and Cintas reported better engagement
numbers when line managers took charge of leading employee engagement instead
of HR managers.

This is an important finding suggesting that business leads can empower
supervisors and hold them accountable for the engagement of their teams while
creating a steady feedback loop.

The onus of employee engagement should be divided between the HR, line
managers, the individual employee, and senior leaders. Top-down commitment
across all departments is necessary to encourage employees' commitment.

Moreover, employees would automatically feel more engaged if they were made a
part of the decisions regarding employee engagement and felt that their
opinions mattered.

## **From Theory to Practice**

A [study by Gallup ](https://www.gallup.com/workplace/236927/employee-
engagement-drives-growth.aspx)found that teams that are deeply engaged are 21%
more productive. That's not all – Other research finds that investing just 10%
more in employee engagement can boost profits by $2,400 per employee annually.

How do you know whether your employee engagement ideas and activities are
working? Here are a few KPIs and questions that would help:

**1\. Engagement beyond work:** How many employees work outside regular
working hours (e.g., evenings and weekends)? Is this a good indicator of their
own initiative, or were they asked to put in extra hours?

**2\. Broader corporate-social networks:** How many network connections does
the average employee have? How much time is spent with people outside of the
immediate team or region? This is a good indicator since passively disengaged
employees tend to have smaller social networks.

**3\. Participation without obligations:** What is the percentage of
participation in ad-hoc meetings and initiatives that are unplanned and
unstructured as opposed to recurring meetings and group events? For example,
do more employees attend team meetings where they feel attendance is mandatory
as opposed to casual team lunches?

**4\. Branded communications:** Is any time spent in collaborating directly
with customers or outsiders beyond the normal scope of work? How are these
interactions? Is the company brand upheld with pride?

The KPIs and questions above are ones that you should keep an eye on.

Employee engagement activities must blend into a broader strategy and your
company's culture to be truly effective. Without this, you are left with what
Joelle Kaufman (CMO at Dynamic Signal) calls "fireworks and smoke."

"One common mistake is what I call 'the fireworks and the smoke.' When it gets
started, there's a lot of excitement, swag, a party. But a few weeks later,
the fireworks are over and there's just smoke. This is not a program or a
campaign. It's a fundamental way of operating. If you want to engage
employees, you have to be consistently putting out content that solicits
engagement. It can't be just fireworks and smoke," she
[said](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/interviews/employee-engagement/building-
a-culture-of-organizational-engagement-in-conversation-with-joelle-kaufman-
cmo-at-dynamic-signal/).

Employee engagement initiatives should go beyond protecting the bottom line –
they should be a way of life at work.
[Gallup](https://www.gallup.com/workplace/236927/employee-engagement-drives-
growth.aspx) reported 37% less absenteeism, 90% less turnover, and 28% less
safety incidents in organizations with higher employee engagement scores.

If you find yourself stuck for new ways to improve engagement levels in your
organization, give these ideas a shot. Remember to measure their effectiveness
and keep modifying the concept to suit your employees' needs.

# Readers Choice 2019: Best HR Tech - Outsourcing Solution

BIPO Service has won the Gold Award for Best HR Tech - Outsourcing Solution at
the 2019 Readers Choice Awards.

By: [HRM Asia Newsroom](https://hrmasia.com/author/hrmasia/ "Posts by HRM Asia
Newsroom") | December 10, 2019

Topics: [HR Technology](https://hrmasia.com/category/topics/hrtechnology/) |
[News](https://hrmasia.com/category/main/news/) |
[Recruitment](https://hrmasia.com/category/topics/recruitment/) |
[Singapore](https://hrmasia.com/category/markets/singapore/) | [Southeast
Asia](https://hrmasia.com/category/markets/asean/)

![](https://hrmasia.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/IMG_8090-resized-1.jpg)

Outsourcing is becoming a viable option for many types of companies. We
increasingly live in a global and inter-connected workplace, allowing
companies to capitalise on cheaper labour costs elsewhere.

Technology and software solutions also play a role in making sure companies
can operate their businesses across borders with confidence and precision.
That’s why HRM Asia has a category focusing on Best HR Technology –
Outsourcing in the 2019 Readers Choice Awards.

And picking up the Gold Award this year was **BIPO Service**. The company said
the win was largely due to its innovative, easy-to-use products that offer
users connectivity and flexibility via an integrated platform. These are
readily available on the cloud and mobile.

Albert Liew, General Manager of BIPO Singapore, said: “Our win is complemented
by the relationships and peer-to-peer connections we have established
globally. It is a testament of our credibility and on-the-ground support we
have garnered in each of the key markets we operate’’.

BIPO is known in the industry as an HR tech company that provides digitised HR
solutions. From its research and development, product and implementation teams
to business development and finance, it takes pride in ensuring that these
core values are communicated to its clients through careful interaction with
them.

[![](http://hrmasia.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/IMG_8084-resized-and-
cropped.jpg)](http://hrmasia.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/IMG_8084-resized-
and-cropped.jpg)Picking up the Silver award was **Times Software** , a company
that has more than 20 years of experience in the HR, information technology,
and finance sectors. Rene Wong, Marketing Manager of Times Software (pictured,
left), said: “We produce quality HR Solutions that can cater the needs of our
clients from all industries right here in Singapore as well as clients from
other Asian countries’’.

After thanking HRM Asia for these prestigious awards, Wong added: “They
motivate us to go further beyond what’s possible in making great HR products
and delivering great services to all companies here in Singapore and beyond”.

**BIPO Service**

BIPO is a leading one-stop human resources provider in Asia-Pacific, focused
on providing organisations with innovative ways to manage complex end-to-end
HR processes. Through our cloud and mobile-based HR Management system as well
as industry-leading solutions such as Payroll Outsourcing, Attendance
Automation, Business Intelligence, HR Consulting, Recruitment & Business
Process Outsourcing and Flexible Employee Management, we help companies
transform their HR operations to and beyond their expectations, while
achieving business goals related to cost and profitability.

[www.biposervice.com](http://www.biposervice.com)

|  |

**Times Software**

Times Software Pte Ltd is a privately owned, home-grown company, incorporated
in 1998.

As the industry leader with many years of experience in the HR, information
technology and finance sectors, we continuously achieve our mission to provide
excellent products and services to cater to the needs of our clients from all
industries.

Our core products are our comprehensive suite of award-winning TIMES Payroll
and cloud enabled HRIS applications. We also provide Payroll and HR
Outsourcing services, E-Portal services and custom HR solutions.

[www.timesoftsg.com.sg](http://www.timesoftsg.com.sg)

# Time and Attendance Tracking experts Mitrefinch Acquires ASA to enter the US
Market

Mitrefinch recently completed their acquisition of Advance Systems America
(ASA) of Boston, MA, which will allow them to leverage ASA’s expertise and
experience in dealing with complex US union and labor rules.

Mitrefinch USA is a progressive software company that provides intelligent
employee management and biometric time and attendance solutions for large and
midsize companies.

Mitrefinch delivers innovative [Workforce Management
Software](https://mitrefinch.com/features) systems that help maximize
workforce productivity, control labor costs, accurately manage and pay
employees and maintain corporate security.

The Workforce Management Software system, designed to accommodate 100 – 10 000
number of employees, is comprised of six basic modules: Time & Attendance
Software; Absence Management Software; HR Management Software; Employee
Scheduling Software; Mobile Workforce Management; and Employee Self Service.

![](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==)![](https://www.techbullion.com/wp-
content/uploads/2019/10/time-clock-software.png)

Mitrefinch’s [Time and Attendance system](https://mitrefinch.com/all-
solutions/time-management-software/) can eliminate “buddy punching” and wasted
time, reduce errors, build trust between employees and management, drive
change and quickly start paying back a company’s return on investment. Absence
Management controls provides real-time workforce visibility and will detect
any abuse, anomalies, or trends.

HR Management reduces time spent on administrative tasks through easy storage
and instant access of employee records, as well as the generation of detailed
workforce reports on labor activity.

Employee Scheduling & Forecasting Software allows managers to collect and
analyze data such as rates of pay, skills, and employee availability. This
helps prevent unnecessary downtime and productivity losses while ensuring the
necessary skillsets are accounted for at each shift.

Mobile Workforce Management allows remote and off-site employees to seamlessly
clock in and out using any device and provides management with the tools to
verify employee hours using GPS tracking and ensure accurate timekeeping and
compliance issues.

Mitrefinch’s Employee Self Service system allows both on-site and remote
workers the flexibility to access their schedules and request time-off online,
which their managers can quickly accept or deny. Having employees control
their own time management allows HR and supervisors to focus on their many
other administrative duties.

In addition to the many innovative features included with its earlier
Integrated Time & Attendance, Scheduling, Biometric Time Clock, Mobile
Workforce & HR Solutions software, Mitrefinch is proud to announce newly
developed features in its latest version 8.1 release.

These include advanced messaging functionality, business intelligence
integration, unlimited language packs, embedded real time reporting
capability, remote custom widget builder, the ability to embed external
resources, TMS for outlook with full ESS support, TMS for Mobile with full ESS
support, access ability on smart devices, and customizable dashboards.

Mitrefinch US sales manager, Peter Bellotti, says the company’s customizable
approach is the key to its success. Mitrefinch services many industries
including construction; energy, utilities and resources; financial services;
government and public services; healthcare services; hospitality and leisure;
manufacturing; retail and consumer; transportation and logistics.

To learn more about how Mitrefinch’s biometric time and attendance solutions
can benefit your business visit [mitrefinch.com ](https://mitrefinch.com)

## **6 Useful Ideas for Retaining Employees in 2020**

Recent research suggests that companies need a proactive strategy for
retaining employees. More than three out of four employees who left an
organization in 2019 could have been retained, according to a [Work Institute
study covering 250,000 US
employees](http://info.workinstitute.com/retentionreport2019).

There can be several causes of
[attrition](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/employee-engagement/what-
is-attrition-complete-guide/). Black shared an example: “According to Glint
data, employees are six times more likely to consider leaving their
organization if they do not rate their manager highly, compared with those who
do.” The report suggested that 11% of employees could not be retained due to
manager behavior. Career development (22%), and work-life balance (12%) are
the two other leading causes of attrition.

So, how do you control attrition among your workforce and maintain a healthy
retention rate? Here are six tips to consider:

### **1\. Enhance employee experience by focusing on the “little things”**

Satisfactory pay, sufficient leaves, and a fair workload are basic employee
requirements. Apart from this, your workforce could be facing other seemingly
small challenges during their everyday tasks and assignments. For example, the
[time and attendance ](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/workforce-
scheduling/five-features-to-look-for-in-a-time-and-attendance-
system/)mechanism could have bugs, compelling employees to manually mark
attendance and get approvals. Or, employees may opt for a paid leave during
the holiday season, which wasn’t registered – this hampers their work-life
balance.

Over time, these “little things” add up, impacting [employee
experience](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/employee-engagement/what-
is-employee-experience/). By implementing regular pulse surveys, you can stay
up-to-date on employee needs, sentiment, and complaints (if any). This will
help you take course corrective measures.

For example, Costco decided to give its workforce a day off on Thanksgiving –
despite it being peak shopping period. This has helped the company achieve a
[94% retention rate](https://fortune.com/longform/costco-wholesale-shopping/)
for employees who have been there for a year, a number far higher than the
industry average.

### **2\. Help your managers prioritize employee engagement**

[LinkedIn recently analyzed ](https://business.linkedin.com/talent-
solutions/blog/trends-and-research/2019/3-factors-linked-to-better-employee-
retention)32 million profiles to plot a “retention curve,” and it reaffirms
the value of good management. Companies where management was highly rated, had
a 48% chance of retaining employees even after three years. For those with low
management ratings, this number fell to 32%.

“Managers play a critical role in creating a high-performance organization,”
says Black. “Managers impact so much of the employee experience, from helping
their teams stay aligned and on track with goals to having effective
conversations about career development and finding opportunities for their
team members to grow.” Ask employees to review their manager’s performance and
work on [manager engagement](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/employee-
engagement/are-you-taking-care-of-manager-engagement/) as well, as a key
retention measure. You can also look at [AI-driven performance feedback
solutions](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/performance-management-
hcm/ai-driven-performance-feedback/) so managers have the right data and
insights to engage employees.

### **3\. Offer learning and career progression across the employee journey**

In many ways, [career development and
learning](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-development/skills-
for-a-career-in-learning-and-development/) are more valued than benefits. It
boosts employees’ overall employability and ensures that they can find
meaningful opportunities beyond their current role. This is of great value to
any professional and can boost their loyalty to your company to a significant
degree.

In fact, the Work Institute report we cited previously, found that the
percentage of attrition attributed to career development went up by 32%
between 2013 and 2018.

Reimagine employee experience in 2020, from a learning and development
perspective. For example, you can [deploy learning as part of daily
workflows](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-development/how-
to-deploy-workplace-learning-for-maximum-productivity/), to increase
productivity and ensure that the lessons learned are remembered in the long
term. Personalized L&D; and cross-disciplinary training are other key areas
that deserve your attention. This can help in retaining high-potential
workers, as this will be the demographic most interested in developing their
skills.

**Learn More:** **[What Is an Employee Engagement Survey? Definition, Process,
Vendors, and Examples](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/employee-
engagement/what-is-an-employee-engagement-survey-definition-process-vendors-
examples/)**

### **4\. Hold on to tried-and-tested employee engagement initiatives**

Traditional engagement ideas like Casual Friday, in-office contests,
suggestion boxes, Secret Santa during the holiday season, etc. make a big
difference to employee loyalty. Such initiatives foster a sense of community,
so your workforce feels like a connected “family” working towards a shared
vision.

You can complement these initiatives with digital tools – for example, an iPad
positioned in the lobby to collect candid employee suggestions or a Slack
thread dedicated to sharing work-related memes. “Creating a workplace culture
that fosters a sense of belonging ultimately translates to a more engaged and
productive workforce that advocates on behalf of the company they represent,”
says Black.

### **5\. Laterally transition employees to new roles when they are ready**

A high-performing employee might be getting restless with their current job
role and could be interested in new, challenging areas. It’s vital that a
change in responsibilities is available within the company, so your top-
performers do not have to look elsewhere.

The LinkedIn study found that employees who changed jobs internally were more
than 70% more likely to stay on after two years, compared to 56% of those who
didn’t see a change.

And it doesn’t matter whether they are promoted or it’s a lateral change –
either way, it is easier to retain employees by helping them diversify than
keeping them contained within one role.

Leverage [continuous performance
management](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/performance-management-
hcm/what-is-continuous-performance-management-and-4-reasons-you-need-it/) to
pinpoint the right time for a role change. This will help to detect instances
of employees getting complacent, or poor employee-to-job fitment. By keeping
an eye on these indicators, you can initiate a role-change and preempt
attrition.

### **6\. Empower your workers and enable autonomy**

Your employees are eager to find a sense of purpose in their work and take
ownership of tasks, decisions, and business outcomes. That’s why you need to
provide empowerment in the workplace to retain employees successfully.

The LinkedIn study we mentioned found that empowered employees are 47% more
likely to stay with a company after three years, compared to 35% of employees
at a company with low empowerment ratings.

An excellent way to enable autonomy is to implement self-service wherever
possible; this could be [self-service
HR,](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/employee-self-service/4-ways-to-
increase-employee-self-service-adoption/) IT, and analytics. Further, benefits
such as flexible hours and remote working can drive autonomy by allowing
employees to choose how, when, and where they work. Measures like these are
critical to fostering a sense of empowerment, not to mention helping to
achieve the work-life balance your employees need.

**Learn More:** **[How to Train New Employees: 5 Steps for
Planning](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/performance-management-
hcm/how-to-train-new-employees-steps-for-success/)**

## **In 2020, Look Beyond Year-Wise Milestones When Retaining Employees**

We often hear that someone who has stayed with a company for three years or
more is considered “retained.” But their contribution remains valuable beyond
these year-wise milestones. “An effective retention strategy focuses on
ensuring employees are happy at work, learning often, and feeling their
contribution to the organization. As long as these basic needs are met,
employees will not have to look elsewhere for them, not in one year nor in
five years,” says Black.

HR needs to make sure that companies:

  * Recognize and fulfill employees’ career development goals
  * Streamline workplace experiences by removing process-based roadblocks
  * Equip managers with the tools required for heightened engagement
  * Strengthen internal communication so employees feel connected to senior leadership

These strategies can go a long way in retaining employees in today’s
competitive labor market. Take a fiercely employee-centric stance in 2020, and
build a loyal, productive, and future-ready workforce.

# How technology is helping solve the compliance conundrum

Several new tools aim to keep employers on the right side of the law, while
also empowering employees.

By: [Tom Starner](https://hrexecutive.com/author/tom-starner/ "Posts by Tom
Starner") | December 3, 2019 • 5 min read

Topics: [Employment Law](https://hrexecutive.com/category/employmentlaw/) |
[HR Technology](https://hrexecutive.com/category/hrtechnology/) | [Performance
Management](https://hrexecutive.com/category/talentmanagement/performance-
management/) | [Talent
Management](https://hrexecutive.com/category/talentmanagement/) | [Top
Stories](https://hrexecutive.com/category/top-stories/)

![](https://hrexecutive.com/wp-
content/uploads/2018/03/GettyImages-857423708Compliance700-700x450.jpg)

[Keeping up with compliance](https://hrexecutive.com/report-compliance-issues-
continue-to-concern-employers/), a moving target within the human resource
space, affects employers of all sizes. And as compliance continues to grow
more complicated, antiquated systems for staying on the right side of the law
are being replaced by technology-driven solutions that can simplify success in
reducing legal exposure.

One such solution—albeit, a hybrid service comprised of both technology and
the human element—is the recently released ADP Compliance on Demand, a
workforce-management platform designed to help employers perform employee
timekeeping, scheduling, attendance and leave management in ways that simplify
compliance with [wage and hour regulations](https://hrexecutive.com/changes-
are-coming-to-pay-and-wage-rules/), according to David Palmieri, DVP, general
manager at ADP.

“We recognize that business leaders and HR professionals alike need more than
technology,” Palmieri says. “They need a partner with expertise that can be
leveraged to design a solution for the unique complexities of their business.
More than ever, organizations of all sizes are looking for ways to manage wage
and hour compliance.”

According to ADP’s Palmieri, those specific headaches may entail fundamental
matters such as absorbing a change like the [new overtime
rule](https://hrexecutive.com/dol-finally-finalizes-overtime-rule/), where
worker classification and overtime pay are the focus, or more complex multi-
state and jurisdictional pay- and work-rule compliance. In an [ever-changing
regulatory landscape](https://hrexecutive.com/wrestling-with-workplace-
policies-and-regulations/) at the federal, state and local levels, maintaining
a culture of compliance can be especially challenging. ADP Compliance on
Demand, he says, will save business leaders and HR professionals time and
allow them to more easily respond to these multi-layered changes.

Advertisement  
  

Palmieri says the new service includes a comprehensive library of federal,
state and local materials, a compliance helpdesk and a community forum for
crowd-sourcing opinions and best practices.

With Compliance On Demand, ADP teamed up with the mega-employment law firm
Littler Mendelson to enhance the service by incorporating Littler’s GPS
knowledge repository and by offering access to Littler compliance experts
through the helpdesk.

Sharad Gera, vice president of financial operations at Reading, Pa.-based
Penske Truck Leasing, an ADP client, says the convenience of having one source
that covers federal, state and local jurisdictions is a “huge timesaver.”

Gera says Penske operates in a very complex timekeeping and payroll
environment, working across 48 states with union and non-union employees,
noting that Compliance on Demand provides Penske with “timely, well-rounded
perspectives” from ADP Compliance on Demand.

“That guidance and reassurance is extremely valuable,” Gera says.

Scott Forman, a shareholder at Littler, explains that the combined service
will expedite access to compliance information and allow clients to
proactively collaborate with their legal and HR teams.

“That synergy creates a culture of compliance that will not only lead to
business growth, but also to employee satisfaction and wellbeing,” he says.

**Caring for the Elderly, Complying with the Law**

“Ongoing regulatory changes make HR compliance in the U.S. particularly
difficult,” says Ted Malley, chief customer officer at Ceridian, which offers
a compliance component within its Dayforce Payroll, Benefits, Workforce
Management and Performance product. “It’s further complicated by the large
number of jurisdictions with potentially conflicting regulations that can
create uncertainty for HR when determining what is or isn’t allowed.”

In addition, Malley adds, many U.S. employers choose to turn to litigation to
resolve disputes, an issue that increases the risk that a company will end up
in court for a real or perceived violation of labor and employment laws.

“Many elements of compliance headaches could be minimized by adopting an
effective HCM solution,” he says.

At MBK Senior Living, a Ceridian customer that offers independent-living,
assisted-living and memory-care services to seniors across six states
(Washington, Utah, Oregon, Colorado, California and Arizona), access to data
helps the company maintain compliance in an increasingly complex industry.

According to Jeff Fischer, president of MBK Senior Living, based in Irvine,
Calif., Dayforce helps the company automate its training records so that, if
it has to show its records to an auditor or state regulator, MBK can easily
pull them. With the fluctuations in the workforce and the high turnover that
MBK Senior Living periodically faces, Fischer notes, it's critically important
for it to be organized and on top of compliance and training records.

“New technologies in the HR space are crucial to our success in the coming
years,” he says. “With the shortage of talent, and us trying to find new ways
to make our workforce more efficient, Dayforce helps further automate our
processes and find ways to improve the lives of our employees.”

Advertisement  
  

**Turning to the Reporting Channel**

Juliette Gust, founder and president of Ethics Suite, an online workplace-
misconduct and fraud-reporting channel, says keeping current with regulatory
changes around sexual-harassment and discrimination-reporting requirements
means employers should check with outside counsel to ensure they’re complying
with the most current regulatory framework. At the same time, while technology
is a great way to manage the process, the emergence of platforms like social
media carry high risk.

“We see instances where employees are reporting potential misconduct directly
through social media. At times, these employees are circumventing an existing
reporting program,” Gust says, adding it’s critical that employers have a
meaningful and trusted program internally so employees feel they can report to
the employer, and that the employer will follow up with actions necessary to
address concerns or misconduct.

Should an issue become public via social media, employers face the additional
challenge of rehabilitating their program and restoring any lost confidence in
their ability to manage issues internally. Gust says steps should be taken to
help the rehabilitation, including reiterating a strong commitment to
compliance, implementing or reinvesting in an anonymous reporting platform,
training employees on how to communicate issues and company policies, and
communicating the steps the company will take to respond.

In fact, several surveys and studies support the benefits of providing an
internal reporting platform with the [ability to report
anonymously](https://hrexecutive.com/apps-help-anonymously-report-sexual-
harassment/), if desired, she says. The Association of Certified Fraud
Examiners’ 2018 _Report to the Nations on Occupational Fraud and Abuse_ survey
results, for instance, indicated that 46% of fraud cases were detected by
employee tips, and those organizations with hotlines suffered losses that were
50% smaller than those that did not offer a hotline.

Gust says the use of technology should be one of multiple options provided to
employees for reporting wrongdoing (i.e., discuss with supervisor, HR or
legal; or use anonymous-reporting tool via web, email or SMS). It should be
supported by whistleblower and anti-retaliation policies that clearly
communicate to everyone (including vendors and clients or customers) that the
organization has a zero-tolerance policy for retaliation against any person
who reports unethical or illegal behavior in good faith.

“Compliance is not a glamorous area. It is, however, an area where HR must get
things exactly right,” concludes Ceridian’s Malley. “Leadership assumes HR
will have this issue perfectly nailed down. Successful compliance relies on
knowledge of the regulations, experience in applying them, and the appropriate
processes and systems to maintain compliance day to day, week to week and year
to year.”



Tom Starner is a freelance writer based in Philadelphia who has been covering
the human resource space and all of its component processes for over two
decades. He can be reached at hreletters@lrp.com.

# Three Things HR Leaders Should Know For Hiring, Managing And Developing
Talent In 2019

[![Forbes Technology Council](https://blogs-
images.forbes.com/assets/images/avatars/blog-3949_400_6d18078e84d93600baaf18165a1394f8.jpg)](https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbestechcouncil/
"Forbes Technology Council logo")

[Mike
Morini](https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbestechcouncil/people/mikemorini/)Forbes
Councils Member

[Forbes Technology Council](https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbestechcouncil/)

COUNCIL POST

expressed are those of the author.

POST WRITTEN BY

Mike Morini

Mike Morini is the CEO of [WorkForce
Software](http://www.workforcesoftware.com/), the leading cloud-based
workforce management provider for complex, global enterprises.

  * Share to Facebook
  * Share to Twitter
  * Share to Linkedin

Today’s HR leaders have it tough. The first half of 2019 brought with it the[
](https://www.bls.gov/news.release/pdf/empsit.pdf)[lowest unemployment
rate](https://www.bls.gov/news.release/pdf/empsit.pdf) we’ve seen since
[1970](https://data.bls.gov/pdq/SurveyOutputServlet). That’s good news for the
U.S. economy but a challenge for HR teams fighting to attract, retain, and
engage a more financially secure, diverse workforce. With the gig economy in
full force and [new Department of Labor (DOL) proposals frequently being
introduced](https://tax.thomsonreuters.com/blog/dols-regulatory-to-do-list-
tackles-flsa-fmla-and-work-visa-issues/), if the first half of 2019 taught us
anything it’s that flexibility will be the key to successful workforce
management across industries. Further, as technology leaders, it’s incumbent
upon us to find smart ways to alleviate increasing pressure on HR. It’s also
in our best interest, as hiring decisions and employee engagement strategies
can directly impact productivity, agility, and our ability to drive the bottom
line. As the CEO of a company that offers HR software for functions like
scheduling, and time and attendance, here are three things I recommend you
keep in mind when hiring, managing, and developing talent.

**Prepare to ride the regulatory rollercoaster.**

The last few months have [brought
](https://www.shrm.org/resourcesandtools/legal-and-compliance/employment-
law/pages/flsa-overtime-rule-resources.aspx)several proposed updates to the
Department of Labor’s Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). Back in March, the DOL
announced that they would be proposing an
[increase](https://www.dol.gov/newsroom/releases/osec/osec20190307) in the
salary threshold that determines which workers are eligible for overtime.
[Eighteen states](http://www.ncsl.org/research/labor-and-employment/state-
minimum-wage-chart.aspx) went into 2019 with increased minimum wage rates,
including California and Washington. As the House recently [passed
](https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-congress-minimum-wage/house-passes-
bill-to-raise-federal-minimum-wage-to-15-an-hour-idUSKCN1UD2DV)legislation to
raise the federal minimum wage to $15 an hour, and [two-thirds of
Americans](https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2019/07/30/two-thirds-of-
americans-favor-raising-federal-minimum-wage-to-15-an-hour/) are in favor of
the proposal, companies should plan ahead for wage hikes and prepare to offset
extra costs.

Predictive scheduling, aka "fair scheduling" laws -- something my company's
software helps with but that companies can also pursue independently -- have
also begun to gain traction throughout the U.S. [Employees in New York,
Seattle and San Francisco](https://www.epi.org/publication/fair-workweek-laws-
help-more-than-1-8-million-workers/) are already feeling the benefits of
protection from unpredictable work schedules that, in many cases, can deprive
workers of a healthy work-life balance.

**The gig is here to stay.  **

The gig economy continues to take hold both here in the United States and
globally. As of 2016, [over 160 million
workers](https://www.mckinsey.com/featured-insights/employment-and-
growth/independent-work-choice-necessity-and-the-gig-economy) across the
United States and Europe had made the shift to contract work -- meaning that
they engaged in some form of independent work -- and that number will likely
continue to grow. A big driver of this trend could be generational, with
millennials representing [35%](https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-
tank/2018/04/11/millennials-largest-generation-us-labor-force/) of the U.S.
workforce in 2018. As the largest segment of workers in today’s economy, 2016
[Deloitte
research](https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/Deloitte/global/Documents/About-
Deloitte/gx-millenial-survey-2016-exec-summary.pdf) found that 16.8% consider
good work-life balance the strongest reason to work for an organization, and
11% rate flexibility the strongest. That means they may be actively seeking
hourly, contract positions that better fit their lifestyles and, in many
cases, operate outside the typical 9-to-5 hours of salaried jobs.

Unlike previous generations that may have worked one structured, salaried
position with set time off, I've noticed that millennials and Gen Zers
entering the workforce are tipping the labor market toward hourly and contract
employment. These younger generations of employees are breaking the mold of
salaried employment and seeking out roles that allow for flexibility, unlike
their counterparts who may be more likely to strive for consistency within
their careers.

**Organizations should** **  continually** **  evolve to succeed.**

Change is constant. And when it comes to regulatory updates, the never-ending
introduction of new or updated legislation leaves organizations vulnerable to
compliance violations \-- which can end up [costing
companies](https://webapps.dol.gov/elaws/whd/flsa/screen74.asp) thousands of
dollars each year.

To ensure compliance with myriad regulations, companies should have a solid
grasp on how and where their workforce is distributed, both nationally and
internationally. Understanding individual state regulations as they apply to
the FLSA and how your own internal policies align with or extend beyond those
rules will help ensure that your company is not dinged for non-compliance,
which can lead to hefty penalties and fines. On an international scale,
regulations such as the General Data Protection Regulation can greatly impact
the flow of information across companies, and HR departments should be sure
that the right information is being communicated -- and protected -- across
channels. ** ** Additionally, organizations should ensure that any adjustments
made to comply with regulatory changes are communicated clearly to all
employees. Effective change management is essential, which can include
company-wide management trainings around the application of specific
regulatory changes and updating your employee handbook to include changes to
policies related to hiring, onboarding and reporting.

When it comes to predictive scheduling policies, providing advance notice of
schedules to employees is mission-critical for success. Organizations that
make a conscious effort to align employee schedules and preferences with
anticipated business needs can see greater success by ensuring that the right
resources and employees are available at the right times to boost both the
customer experience and bottom-line profits. Similarly, adjusting
organizational teams to redistribute resources based on skills and interests
can lead to significant gains. I've found that companies whose internal
culture supports open communication around these issues see the highest gains,
both in terms of employee engagement and productivity. As leaders, we’re
reminded that corporate brand values should be visible \-- not just on paper,
but also in words and actions. To accomplish this, organizations should create
and nurture effective feedback loops, communicate clearly and often, and relay
resulting action steps back to the workforce.

I believe success in the back half of 2019 will require companies to strike a
balance between the needs of the business and those of its evolving workforce.
As the influx of younger generations continues, which could lead to a more
gig-centric economy, improved transparency and scheduling will likely be
crucial. With the changing perceptions around hourly and gig workers,
companies face more pressure than ever to win and retain this new type of
talent. Having a connected workforce where employees at every level can
operate at peak efficiency could be key to navigating regulatory changes,
engaging an increasingly diverse workforce, and ensuring long-term business
success.

SINGAPORE, Sept. 10, 2019 /PRNewswire/ --
[TalentMind](https://talentmind.ai/), a human resource technology solutions
provider and part of AnyMind Group, has today announced the launch of
_[TalentMind People](https://talentmind.ai/people/)_ , a human resource
management system that helps human resource professionals to digitally track
and manage various employee data points including time attendance, leave
management and an employee database.

![Logo](https://s.yimg.com/g/images/spaceball.gif)![Logo](https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/1KgVd3QUeDb.VyseYpbYEQ--~A/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjtzbT0xO3c9ODAw/https://photos.prnasia.com/prnvar/20181029/2281855-1LOGO)

Logo

More



TalentMind was first launched by AnyMind Group in January 2018, as a
recruitment software that empowers human resource and recruitment
professionals to screen, score, manage and track their recruitment pipeline.
TalentMind features an AI-driven screening system that understands and scores
a candidate's profile to role requirements, learns a company's hiring
preferences, and an applicant tracking system to manage the entire recruitment
process.

The addition of TalentMind People enables human resource professionals to
digitally manage their human resource management processes, with these key
features:

  *  **Time attendance -** Employees have access to various options to view, track and manage their time attendance, including GPS, QR code and biometric. 
  * **Leave management -** Through TalentMind People, employees can view, track and manage their leave applications and requests, and human resource professionals can have an overview of employee absence across the organization, through a single dashboard 
  * **Employee database -** The TalentMind People platform equips human resource professionals with a single dashboard to easily manage employee data

Sho Kondo, Head of TalentMind, said: "With the addition of TalentMind People,
HR can now leverage on TalentMind to build a more data-driven and efficient
approach to recruitment, candidate management, and employee management.
Together with upcoming features such as payroll and performance evaluation, we
are looking to empower HR professionals in Asia with efficiency and synergy
across hiring and employee management."

The TalentMind business is growing strongly in Thailand, with clients in
Thailand like DHL, JAC Recruitment and Siam Makro leveraging on the TalentMind
platform to boost their human resource efforts.

 **About AnyMind Group**

Previously operating as AdAsia Holdings, AnyMind Group was formed in January
2018 and operates three business lines: AdAsia Holdings (advertising),
TalentMind (human resource) and CastingAsia (influencer marketing). AnyMind
Group aims to provide industries, businesses and professionals with a suite of
solutions to enable greater growth. Headquartered in Singapore, AnyMind Group
has over 500 staff from 20 nationalities, across 13 offices in 11 markets. To
date, AnyMind Group has raised a total funding of US$35.9 million, from
investors including (but not limited to) LINE, Mirai Creation Fund, VGI and
JAFCO Asia.

 **About TalentMind**

TalentMind was launched by AnyMind Group in January 2018. The TalentMind
platform offers two broad functions - recruitment (automatic screening and
scoring of a candidate based on role requirements and an ATS) and core human
resource management system, equipping human resource professionals with a tool
to make their activities more data-driven and efficient.

##  Australia:  If a worker refuses biometric fingerprint scanning, is it
unfair dismissal to sack them? Which case won?

22 January 2020

by [Mark Shumsky](/Home/Redirect/1935244?mode=author&article_id=885898 "View
this authors biography on their website")

Stacks Law Firm

__ 0 Liked this Article

[![](/images/profile/individual/1935244.jpg)](/Home/Redirect/1935244?mode=author&article_id=885898
"View this authors biography on their website")

To print this article, all you need is to be registered or login on
Mondaq.com.

## The Facts

### Company introduces site attendance policy with biometric fingerprint
scanning

A company introduced a biometric fingerprint scanning system as part of its
new site attendance policy for all its employees. This measure was intended to
provide security, safety and efficiency benefits for the company.

After the policy was announced during a floor meeting in October 2017, all
company staff were directed to register their fingerprints over the following
week. Once registered, employees would then check in and out of the company's
work sites by using scanners provided at the start and finish of each shift.

### Employee refuses to provide fingerprints

One employee was a casual general hand who had worked at the company for more
than three years. In November 2017 he was called in and attended a meeting,
but did not provide his fingerprints when asked to do so.

The following day he met his supervisors, who provided him with further
information about the site attendance policy and the scanning system. They
provided reasons for the decision to introduce the scanners and the benefits
the system would bring to the company.

### Employee concerns regarding third party access to fingerprint data

The employee said he was not satisfied that the company could guarantee that
third parties would not be able to access the electronically stored
fingerprint data and there was no guarantee that the biometric information in
his prints could not be used by any other persons.

The employee then wrote to the company, setting out his concerns about privacy
and his objection to providing his fingerprints. The company responded with
additional information about the nature of the fingerprint data collection.

The company provided the employee with documentation from the suppliers of the
scanners, which said that the data collected could not be used "for any other
purpose other than linking your payroll number to a clock in/out time".

### Company dismisses employee after discussions and warnings

The scanners were implemented in January 2018. Meanwhile, the employee
continued to check in and out of work using the sign in and out book.

He was given a verbal warning and was subsequently warned in writing that if
he continued to fail to comply with the policy, it would result in his
employment being terminated.

The employee wrote to the company that he wished to be allowed to keep his
job, but insisted on retaining ownership of his biometric data. Further
discussions did not result in any resolution.

In February 2018 a show cause letter was issued to the employee, after which
he was dismissed.

The employee brought an application in the Fair Work Commission for unfair
dismissal. It was up to the commission to determine whether it was reasonable
and lawful for the employer to require the employee to provide the biometric
data and if so, whether the dismissal was harsh, unjust or unreasonable.

### case a - The case for the employer

|

### case b - The case for the employee  
  
---|---  
  
  * Our requirement that employees use biometric fingerprint scanning is lawful, reasonable and practical.
  * This measure is part of our site attendance policy. It improves safety in the event of an emergency by avoiding the need to locate the paper sign in and out book to ascertain attendance on site.
  * The site attendance policy formed part of the employee's contract of employment, so he was obliged to comply with its terms.
  * The biometric data collected by the fingerprint scanners is secure and confidential, as are all employee records.
  * There was no breach of privacy, due to the exemption in the Privacy Act with respect to employee records.
  * We have the right to manage our affairs by requiring employees to comply with company policies.
  * The commission should find that he was not unfairly dismissed.

|

  * My fingerprints and the biometric data they contain constitute "sensitive information" according to the Privacy Act. They are my personal and private property.
  * Employers are not entitled to collect an employee's sensitive information without proper notice and without their consent.
  * The company did not talk to me or to any other employees about its legal obligations and responsibilities in handling sensitive information.
  * The company supplying the scanners also failed to provide adequate information about the collection and use of personal and sensitive information in accordance with Australian privacy laws.
  * Once my personal biometric data is digitised, it could be difficult to contain its use by third parties, including for commercial purposes. I was never told exactly who was likely to have access to this sensitive information.
  * The Privacy Act exemption does not apply to my records, because the company failed to issue a privacy collection notice as required by the Privacy Act.
  * It is not true that the fingerprint scanners would improve safety, nor that their introduction was reasonably necessary. The commission should find that I was unfairly dismissed.

## **What Is Recruitment Software Technology?**

Recruitment technology is defined as a set of tools used to automate the
hiring process, connecting with a variety of data sources to access the best
quality candidates. It performs key functions such as screening applicants,
streamlining follow-ups, and providing data on the efficiency of your
recruitment model.

Over the last few years, the demand for recruitment software and tools has
shot up dramatically as the labor market becomes fiercer and more complicated.
Companies are eager to hire highly skilled workers and drive business
innovation, even as the average tenure per employee continues to dip. In fact,
global market research company Fortune Business Insights finds that the
recruitment software market will cross $3,000 million by 2025.

Interestingly, recruitment doesn’t always need to be a technology-driven
process. However, if you’re looking for high-quality talent that makes an
excellent culture fit, especially during a rapid growth phase, you will
require recruitment software to achieve the right level of efficiency.

Recruitment software doesn’t just help you complete the formalities around
hiring a candidate. It automates the entire recruitment pipeline right from
candidate sourcing and engagement to the final step of onboarding. That’s why
it has become a staple for the **[modern HR
toolkit](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/digital-transformation/hr-
toolkit-of-the-future/)**.

## **Four Features of Recruitment Software That Should Be on Your Checklist**

Given the highly crowded nature of the recruitment software marketplace, how
do you go about choosing one best suited to your enterprise? Are you aware of
all the must-have features in any recruitment platform, and future trends in
this space?

Here are a few key features that your recruitment software and tools should be
able to perform:

### **1\. Plugging into a variety of data sources**

  
The recruitment tool of your choice should be able to **integrate with the
highest possible number of data sources** , including social media, email, job
boards, third-party staffing platforms, and several other **[talent
sourcing](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/digital-transformation/what-
is-talent-sourcing/)** areas. It should also come with the requisite sort-and-
filter capabilities to help find the right talent.

### **2\. Deploying recruitment marketing initiatives**

  
Today, attracting and retaining candidates closely resembles the process of
attracting and retaining consumers. That’s why it is a recruitment best
practice to **approach the hiring process as a sales and marketing campaign**.

Remember to check if a recruitment software supports email automation, job ads
publishing, video communication, **[candidate relationship
management](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/recruitment-
onboarding/what-is-candidate-relationship-management/)** (CRM), and in-app
messaging to engage with applicants across the entire hiring journey.

### **3\. Shortlisting candidate profiles**

  
With so many recommendations and leads flowing in from multiple sources, it
could be challenging to arrive at **an actionable list of candidates** – and
this is particularly true for bulk-hiring campaigns.

Recruitment software should be able to build a searchable database of
applicants, perform level-one resume screening, enable multi-channel
communication within the platform, and aid your end-to-end selection process.

### **4\. Revealing insights into recruitment efficiency**

  
This is one of the most significant advantages of using an analytics-driven
recruitment software versus legacy manual processes. The tool should be able
to gather data across the recruitment pipeline to **extract useful insights,**
such as which sourcing strategy is performing the best, whether your
time/cost-to-hire is sustainable, and key pain points in the **[candidate
experience](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/recruitment-
onboarding/what-is-candidate-experience-definition-components-technology/)**.

Over time, this feature will ensure your recruitment function becomes smarter,
more effective, and ready to stand out in a competitive hiring arena.

Now that we’ve looked at the core features of recruitment software, let's turn
the spotlight on some of the most prominent players in this space and a few
disruptors that are making game-changing strides in recruitment software
technology.

## **The Best Recruitment Software and Tools for 2020**

As technology evolves in leaps and bounds, powerful software and cutting-edge
innovation aren’t limited to large enterprises anymore. For example, Software-
as-a-Service (SaaS) has made it possible to deploy recruitment tools on a pay-
per-use model, scaling up or down as necessary. APIs also enable easier
integrations without any complex back-end development.

As a result, our list of the best recruitment software for 2020 is a mix of
enterprise-grade tools as well as smartly designed products for small and
medium-sized businesses (SMBs). We have tried to cover the varying needs of
businesses of multiple sizes, and every software has excellent online customer
reviews. Remember, the best recruitment software for you will depend on your
unique business requirements – that’s why the numbering on this list doesn’t
reflect the ranking of a particular recruitment tool.

![The best recruitment software to set you up for 2020 and
beyond](/images/ajax-loader.png)

**Fig 1. The best recruitment software to set you up for 2020 and beyond**

### **1\. Ascendify: With the power of predictive intelligence**

  
Ascendify is a talent acquisition software that is powered by state-of-the-art
predictive analytics, which lets you build deeper relationships with
candidates. Further, the recruitment tool’s machine learning capabilities make
it incrementally more useful with every hiring cycle. This is in addition to
recruitment software staples such as career sites, employee referrals, an ATS,
and easy employee onboarding.

Two features deserve special mention when it comes to Ascendify. First, the
new Ascendify Aspire, which uses AI to chart a career progression path for
internal talent management. Second, built-in diversity compliance at the
talent sourcing stage, which can help you meet your **[diversity
hiring](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/diversity/5-channels-that-
offer-qualified-referrals-for-diversity-hiring/)** goals. For hiring at the
enterprise level, Ascendify may prove a suitable software to meet your needs.

### **2\. ADP Workforce Now® Recruitment: Enterprise-grade talent management**

  
ADP is an HR technology giant, and the company’s Workforce Now suite covers a
host of task management features, including recruitment. This recruitment tool
has a comprehensive job posting feature (career website, videos, emails,
social media, etc.) in addition to an automated candidate review process. It
also generates time-to-hire and cost-to-hire reports, so that you’re always
updated about the performance of the recruitment pipeline.

ADP’s recruitment software is available as part of its 360-degree HR offering
– therefore, it is natively integrated with workforce management, performance
reviews, and compensation planning platforms.

### **3\. Freshteam: Blends into your business software suite**

  
Freshteam is an HR and recruitment tool by Freshworks, a company that provides
a range of business solutions to small and mid-sized enterprises. Freshteam
includes hiring, onboarding, and employee data management all within a single
platform.

Importantly, Freshteam is meant to be a one-stop answer to your everyday HR
requirements. It comes with a centralized dashboard for employee time &
attendance, a dedicated hiring module, and an organizational chart.
Freshteam’s built-in ATS makes job posting, hiring team setup, and information
gathering a breeze, with a set of powerful customizations. Also, its
onboarding module automates key activities such as follow-ups and document
sharing to speed up time-to-hire.

Freshteam’s website reveals that SMBs around the globe use its recruitment
software in areas as diverse as pharmaceuticals, media, and technology.

### **4\. happierHire by happierWork: Cloud-based recruitment for small
businesses**

  
The most impressive thing about the happierHire recruitment tool is probably
its sheer simplicity. It plugs into social recruitment touchpoints to expand
your applicant base, its auto-extraction algorithm helps to upload and sort
resumes in bulk, and there is a happierBOT to keep track of the tasks involved
in the recruitment process.

Like a lot of tools on this list, happierHire includes a built-in ATS to
simplify the candidate experience and integrates with a variety of sourcing
platforms.

What makes happierHire a suitable tool for SMBs is probably its attractive
price point as well as a suite of optional add-ons like workflow automation,
intranet, compensation, and compliance – designed for greater flexibility for
small businesses.

### **5\. JazzHR: A recruitment software with seamless integrations**

  
What jumps out at first glance with this recruitment software option is its
endless list of integrations, supported by a robust network of partners. From
internal systems like **[human resource information systems
(HRIS)](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/performance-management-
hcm/what-is-hris/)** , time and attendance, and scheduling tools to third-
party software for background checks, candidate assessment, and tax
compliance, JazzHR appears to have it all.

This recruitment tool includes a built-in ATS, in-app collaboration to quickly
gather ideas from your hiring team, as well as a dedicated offer management
module. Finally, JazzHR enables custom reporting to help build a **[data-
driven recruitment](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/recruitment-
onboarding/how-to-implement-datadriven-recruiting-in-your-talent-acquisition-
team/)** function.

**Learn More:**[ **Top 10 Employee Recruitment Strategies to Hire the Best
Talent**](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/recruitment-onboarding/top-
employee-recruitment-strategies/)

### **6\. Jobvite: A candidate-focused recruiting tool**

  
Jobvite places the candidate experience squarely at the center of the
recruitment process. You can expect a plethora of marketing capabilities, such
as recruitment branding and mobile-optimized career websites. There’s also an
easy-to-navigate **[applicant tracking system
(ATS)](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/recruitment-onboarding/top-
applicant-tracking-systems/)** , **[social media
recruiting](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/recruitment-
onboarding/social-media-recruiting-dos-and-donts/)** capabilities, an
onboarding module, and integrations with other HR systems.

Thanks to the HR software’s integration capabilities, you can access detailed
insights on hiring performance and how it is impacting your overall workforce
management. It’s no surprise then that leading companies such as Schneider
Electric recruit using Jobvite.

### **7\. Workday Recruiting: End-to-end recruitment and HR software**

  
Workday is another industry leader when it comes to recruitment software and
tool providers and is suitable for enterprise-level, large-scale hiring
requirements. Workday Recruiting is implemented as part of its expansive HR
solutions suite, delivering seamless experiences to every stakeholder
involved. Workflow automation, analytics dashboards, branded career sites,
social support, and in-app scheduling are only some of the features that make
Workday a flagship recruitment software.

We are particularly drawn to the tool’s ability to manage referrals. With
referrals and internal hiring taking center stage in the modern **[talent
pipeline](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/digital-transformation/what-
is-talent-pipeline/)** , features such as pan-organization endorsement,
referral leaderboards, and recommendation gathering will be pretty useful for
recruiters.

### **8\. SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting and Onboarding: A top choice for mid-
to-large-sized companies**

  
When it comes to recruitment software tools, SAP’s SuccessFactors has always
been a standout offering. Gartner Peer insights named it a top customer choice
in 2018, and SAP continues to rule the market as we move into 2020.

SuccessFactors is deployed entirely on the cloud, and its biggest USP is
probably the overall capabilities of SAP’s HR suite. The solution is designed
for superior experience quality across the employee journey, including the
recruitment stage. Candidates hired via SuccessFactors display a 32% lower
turnover on average, claims the SAP website.
